arm_group.description: The postoperative pain management includes both the intrathecal morphine injection and the intravenous patient-controlled analgesia.
The postoperative pain management includes only the intravenous patient-controlled analgesia.

brief_summary.textblock:
This study will investigate the efficacy and safety of intrathecal morphine for the patients
      undergoing robot-assisted prostatectomy

detailed_description.textblock:
Prostatectomy is the treatment of choice for prostate cancer. The robot-assisted
      prostatectomy is becoming the most popular surgical method for prostate cancer. The small
      incision after robot-assisted prostatectomy is thought to reduce the postoperative pain.
      There is few investigations for the strategy to reduce the  postoperative pain of
      robot-assisted prostatectomy.

      The intrathecal morphine injection is known to reduce postoperative pain for surgeries like
      hepatectomy, myomectomy and open prostatectomy. This method, however, is not yet studied for
      the robot-assisted prostatectomy. This study will investigate the efficacy and safety of
      intrathecal morphine for the patients undergoing robot-assisted prostatectomy.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients scheduled for the open nephrectomy

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients with renal insufficiency

          -  Patients with coagulopathy

          -  History of any neurologic disorder

          -  History of recent infection in 2 weeks

          -  History of drug abuse

          -  Patients who cannot understand the usage of th intravenous patient-controlled
             analgesia

          -  Patients using opioids due to the chronic pain

intervention.description: The intravenous injection of morphine using the patient-controlled analgesia machine
A single injection of morphine intrathecally

clinical_study.official_title: The Efficacy of Intrathecal Morphine in Patients Undergoing Robot-assisted Prostatectomy

primary_outcome.description: The doctor blinded to the investigation will visit patients. The pain will be assessed at rest and at coughing using visual analogue scale.
primary_outcome.measure: The evaluation of pain at 24 hours after surgery

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: The total amount of opioids (IV morphine) used for 24 hours after surgery will be recorded and compared.
The total amount of intraoperative opioids (IV remifentanil) will be recorded and compared.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From the induction of anesthesia till the emergence of anesthesia, an expected average of 4 hours

secondary_outcome.description: Any side effects of opioids including nausea, vomiting, dizziness, sedation, headache, pruritus and respiratory depression will be recorded.
secondary_outcome.measure: The side effects of opioids after surgery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During 72 hours after the end of surgery

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
